t: Isaiah 23
A Pronouncement against Tyre
A*p pronouncement concerning Tyre: Wail,*pn ships of Tarshish, for*ln your haven has been destroyed. Word*ln has reached them from the land of Cyprus.
Mourn,*ln inhabitants of the coastland, you*ln merchants of Sidon; your*ln agents have crossed the sea
over*ln deep water. Tyre’s*ln revenue was the grain from Shihor — the*ln harvest of the Nile. She*ln was the merchant among the nations.
Be*ln ashamed, Sidon, the stronghold of the sea, for*ln the sea has spoken: “I*ln have not been in labor or given birth. I*ln have not raised young men or*ln brought up young women.”
When*ln the news reaches Egypt, they*ln will be in anguish over the news about Tyre.
Cross*ln over to Tarshish; wail,*ln inhabitants of the coastland!
Is*ln this your jubilant city, whose*ln origin was in ancient times, whose*ln feet have taken her to*ln reside far away?
Who*ln planned this against Tyre, the*ln bestower of crowns, whose*ln traders are princes, whose*ln merchants are the honored ones of the earth?
The*ln Lord*s of Armies planned it, to*ln desecrate all its glorious beauty, to*ln disgrace all the honored ones of the earth.
Overflow*ln your land like the Nile, daughter of Tarshish; there*ln is no longer anything to restrain you.
He*ln stretched out his hand over the sea; he*ln made kingdoms tremble. The*ln Lord*s has commanded that*ln the Canaanite fortresses be destroyed.
He*ln said, “You*ln will not celebrate anymore, ravished*ln young woman, daughter of Sidon. Get*ln up and cross over to Cyprus— even*ln there you will have no rest!”

Look*ln at the land of the Chaldeans — a*ln people who no longer exist. Assyria*ln destined it for desert creatures. They*ln set up their siege towers and*ln stripped its palaces. They*ln made it a ruin.
Wail,*ln ships of Tarshish, because*ln your fortress is destroyed!
On*p that day Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years — the life span of one king. At the end of seventy years, what the song says about the prostitute will happen to Tyre:
Pick*pn up your lyre, stroll*ln through the city, you*ln forgotten prostitute. Play*ln skillfully, sing*ln many a song so*ln that you will be remembered.
And*p at the end of the seventy years, the Lord*s will restore Tyre and she will go back into business, prostituting herself with all the kingdoms of the world throughout the earth.

But her profits and wages will be dedicated to the Lord.*s They will not be stored or saved, for her profit will go to those who live in the Lord’s*s presence, to provide them with ample food and sacred clothing.
